name: Min Kyung Lee
content: Min Kyung Lee, Ph.D. Min Kyung Lee SELECTED HIGHLIGHTS Our Matchmaking with AI paper received the CSCW24 Best Paper Honorable Mention award. Ô∏è I was honored to participate in the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy (OSTP) event on Open by Design: Participatory Algorithm for Equity and Inclusion and give a keynote at the MIDAS Ethical AI symposium at the University of Michigan. We organized a workshop on Human-AI Alignment: Developing a Research Agenda by Bridging Interdisciplinary Approaches at the TAS conference! Our PhD student, Angie Zhang, ran a co-design workshop as part of the worker training on AI, which was organized by International Labour Organization. I am an assistant professor in the UT Austin School of Information, and a director of the Human-AI Interaction Lab. I am also core faculty of the campus-wide Ethical AI Program, and affiliated with Machine Learning Lab, Good Systems, and Texas Robotics. Our work is possible thanks to the National Science Foundation, Good Systems, and Swedish Research Council. I am a human-computer interaction researcher who combines computer science, design, and social science theories and methods. I conducted some of the first studies that empiricially examine the AI's social implications on work, management, and governance. I coined the term Algorithmic Management, and proposed the Procedural Justice Framework for AI to address the misalignment between AI assumptions and stakeholder priorities. My vision is that Participatory AI, which enables stakeholder participation across the AI development cycle, can better align AI with stakeholder priorities and contribute to creating just, empowering workplaces and cities. I strive to translate my research into pragmatic systems and processes to make the real-world impact or support organizations that promote equity and social good. Our WeBuildAI participatory algorithm is adopted by Food Rescue Hero; we are conducting research to assist public administration using technology. Some of our current partners include Austin Transportation Department, King County, Washington, Food Rescue Hero, and Dilligent Robotics. October 2020 Gave a Data Science seminar talk titled "AI for all: Enabling participatory and procedurally-fair AI" at the Seoul National University September 2020 Organizing an IUI workshop on XAI for social justice August 2020 Serving as an Area Chair for ACM FAccT 2021 August 2020 Received a NSF Smart & Connected Communities (SCC) grant on Empowering Gig Workers Through Building A Community-Centered Gig Economy June 2020 Gave an invited talk at Assured Autonomy Workshop on responsible autonomy May 2020 Received a NSF RAPID grant on Trust in Public Health Information During a Pandemic Mar 2020 Gave a AI seminar at UC San Diego on Fair and Participatory AI for all Jan 2020 Received a NSF Fairness in Artificial Intelligence (FAI) grant on Advancing Fairness in AI with Human-Algorithm Collaborations Dec 2019 Leading the CHI2020 workshop on Fair & Responsible AI Dec 2019 Received a UT Healthcare Technology, Communication, & Privacy seed grant July 2019 Two papers at CSCW 2019: WeBuildAI: Participatory Framework for Algorithmic Governance and Procedural Justice in Algorithmic Fairness July 2019 Gave a talk titled "Procedural Justice in Algorithmic Fairness: Transparency, Control and Participation Perspectives" at Simons Institute Workshop on Recent Developments in Research on Fairness June 2019 WeBuildAi and algorithmic participation received Popular Poster Award at the Mechanism Design for Social Good Workshop June 2019 Gave a talk on Algorithmic Management fo
